questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lingual nerve

 

Lingual Nerve: This is the branch of mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It runs close to the submandibular gland and is therefore at risk during submandibular gland surgery.

 

Sensory Distribution: Provides general sensory (pain, temperature, touch) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. (Note: Taste sensation for this region is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, which joins the lingual nerve for a short course.)

 

Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

 

 

Injury:

 

Because dissection of the submandibular duct from the nerve is required during submandibular gland resection, the lingual nerve is at risk of injury. It is also linked to the submandibular ganglion, which will expose the nerve within the operating field.

 

The symptoms of lingual nerve injury differ depending on whether the lesion is proximal or distal to the point where it is joined by the chorda tympani nerve.

 

  • Proximal injury: There is loss of sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, gingivae, oral mucosa, lower lip, and chin.
  • Distal injury: In addition to features of proximal injury, secretion from the salivary glands below the oral fissure and taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is also lost.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nerve to Mylohyoid: This nerve is a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3). It descends on the medial surface of the mandible in the mylohyoid groove.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in the elevation of the hyoid bone and floor of the mouth during swallowing and speech.

 

Option B. Inferior Alveolar Nerve: It's a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It enters the mandibular foramen and runs through the mandibular canal.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Does not directly supply any muscles.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the mandibular teeth, lower lip, and chin.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option D. Hypoglossal Nerve (12th Cranial Nerve): This cranial nerve exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal and supplies the muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies almost all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except the palatoglossus (which is innervated by the vagus nerve).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Tongue deviation to the side of the lesion due to weakened tongue muscles on that side. If you asked the patient to protrude their tongue, it would point towards the side of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

 

Explanation

 

In the above scenario, the patient has developed paresis (partial paralysis) but the pain sensation is intact (no numbness) suggests A fibers involvement as they carry motor, touch, and pressure sensations are most sensitive to pressure changes/compression.

 

A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception (the sense of one's body position). C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated and transmit slower pain signals. While both types of fibers can be affected by pressure, A fibers are more vulnerable to damage from sustained pressure than C fibers, which are more resistant to compression.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers. - Incorrect. C fibers are unmyelinated and relatively more resistant to pressure compared to myelinated A fibers.

 

Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers. - Not relevant to the scenario, as the issue is related to mechanical pressure, not oxygen deprivation.

 

Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers. - Also not relevant to the given scenario, focusing on hypoxia instead of the impact of mechanical pressure or compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative susceptibility -

choices.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.
There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

 

Individuals who are sleepwalking typically act without conscious awareness and usually have no memory of the episode upon awakening.

 

Other Options:

 

Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a disorder of arousal from slow-wave sleep.

 

Option A. Disorder of sleep arousal: True. Sleepwalking arises from deep, non-REM (NREM) stage 4 sleep, making it a disorder of arousal.

 

Option C. Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion: True. When sleepwalkers are awakened, they are often disoriented and confused.

 

Option D. There may be neurological conditions associated: True. While many cases of somnambulism have no clear cause, certain neurological conditions can be associated with it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep. Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colchicine

 

Colchicine is primarily used to treat gout and familial Mediterranean fever. One of its mechanisms of action is the inhibition of neutrophil migration into inflamed tissues, thereby reducing inflammation. It disrupts the microtubules inside cells, including neutrophils, affecting their mobility and reducing their recruitment to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Montelukast: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used mainly for asthma and allergic rhinitis. While it can reduce inflammation, its primary action is not on neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option B. Sodium Cromolyn: Sodium cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer used to treat conditions like asthma and allergic rhinitis. It prevents the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators from mast cells but doesn't directly inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option D. Febuxostat: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used for the treatment of chronic gout. It reduces uric acid production but doesn't specifically inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Therefore, Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment by disrupting microtubules, thus affecting neutrophil mobility and reducing inflammation. This mechanism makes it effective in treating conditions like gout and familial Mediterranean fever.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is referred to a neurologist with complaints of facial flushing and sweating while eating or even just thinking about food. The patient reports that this has been happening for several months and is becoming increasingly bothersome. Upon further questioning, the patient also reports a history of parotid gland surgery for a benign tumor several years ago. Which nerve is involved in Frey's syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Frey's syndrome is a rare condition that occurs as a complication of parotid gland surgery or other trauma to the area. It is characterized by facial flushing and sweating in the region of the face associated with the parotid gland, particularly when eating or thinking about food. The underlying cause of Frey's syndrome is damage to the auriculotemporal nerve (a branch of the mandibular nerve, V3). This damage results in abnormal nerve regeneration and cross-connection between the parasympathetic fibers that stimulate salivation and the sympathetic fibers that control sweating.

 

  • Mechanism: The auriculotemporal nerve contains both sensory fibers and parasympathetic secretomotor fibers that supply the parotid gland. Following injury or surgery, these fibers can aberrantly regenerate, causing parasympathetic fibers to innervate sweat glands of the overlying skin, leading to sweating and flushing upon salivation.

 

Treatment Options:

 

  • Topical Antiperspirants: These can help reduce sweating by blocking sweat glands.
  • Oral Medications: Medications that reduce sweating may be prescribed.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injections: These injections can block the action of sweat glands, providing relief from symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve controls facial expressions and can be injured during parotid surgery, leading to facial palsy. However, it is not involved in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve: The oculomotor nerve controls eye movements and pupil constriction and is not involved in the innervation of the parotid gland or the region affected in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is involved in taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue and parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland. However, it is not directly involved in the facial flushing and sweating characteristic of Frey's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frey's syndrome is caused by damage to the auriculotemporal nerve, leading to abnormal sweating and flushing of the face associated with eating or thinking about food. This condition is a common complication of parotid gland surgery.

questions.text: Identify the histological structure shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pancreatic islet cells

 

  • The pancreas has two main parts: the exocrine and endocrine pancreas.
  • The endocrine part of the pancreas is composed of islets of Langerhans, which are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and numerous fenestrated capillaries.
  • Each islet is surrounded by a delicate capsule and appears paler than the surrounding exocrine cells due to the presence of less rough endoplasmic reticulum.
  • The image provided depicts the histology of the pancreas.

 

 

Pancreatic Islet Cells (Islets of Langerhans): Scattered throughout the pancreas, these islets are endocrine clusters differing from the surrounding exocrine pancreatic tissue.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Alpha Cells: Produce glucagon which increases blood glucose levels.
  • Beta Cells: The most common islet cell, producing insulin which decreases blood glucose levels.
  • Delta Cells: Produce somatostatin, which regulates the other islet cells.
  • Gamma Cells (PP or F cells): Produce pancreatic polypeptide, which regulates some of the pancreatic exocrine and endocrine functions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymph Node: Lymph nodes are small, bean-shaped structures found throughout the lymphatic system.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Capsule: A dense connective tissue covering.
  • Trabeculae: Extensions from the capsule that divide the node into compartments.
  • Cortex: Contains densely packed lymphocytes and has follicles with germinal centers.
  • Medulla: Central part containing medullary cords (lymphatic tissue) and medullary sinuses filled with lymph.
  • Hilum: The area where blood vessels and nerves enter and exit and where the efferent lymphatic vessels leave the node.

 

Option B. Glomerulus: A tuft of capillaries situated within Bowman's capsule in the nephron of the kidney.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Endothelial Cells: These line the inner surface of the capillaries.
  • Basement Membrane: Lies between the endothelial cells and the podocytes, playing a critical role in filtering the blood.
  • Podocytes: These are specialized epithelial cells that cover the outer surfaces of the glomerular capillaries. Their foot processes interdigitate and form filtration slits.
  • Mesangial Cells: Located between the capillary loops and provide structural support and phagocytic functions.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ that filters blood and is involved in immune reactions.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Capsule: Dense connective tissue with smooth muscle cells.
  • Trabeculae: Extensions from the capsule containing blood vessels.
  • White Pulp: Lymphatic tissue arranged around arterioles (central arteries). It's involved in immune responses.
  • Red Pulp: Consists of splenic cords (reticular connective tissue with many blood-filled sinuses). It filters the blood of antigens, microorganisms, and defective or worn-out red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with pain in the right thigh during walking. Investigation reveals a finding as shown below. What will be the most appropriate surgical management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortofemoral bypass

 

  • Pain in the thigh while walking and MR angiography showing right common iliac artery non-visualisation suggest peripheral obstructive vascular disease with right common iliac obstruction.
  •  As the disease progresses, rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene may occur.
  • Aortofemoral bypass surgery is a procedure to create a new route for blood flow to the lower extremities by bypassing the blocked segment of the aorta and/or the common iliac arteries.
  • A graft (DACRON), which is typically made from a synthetic material, is used to create this new route.
  •  The graft is sutured proximally to the aorta and distally to the femoral arteries.
  •  Given the scenario where there is obstruction of the common iliac artery and the patient is experiencing pain in the thigh during walking, which is suggestive of claudication due to iliac disease, the aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTA with stenting: PTA (Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty) involves the insertion of a catheter through the skin and into the obstructed artery. The catheter has a tiny balloon at its tip which, once in place, is inflated to widen the artery and restore blood flow. A stent (a tiny mesh tube) is then placed in the newly opened artery to help keep it open. This minimally invasive procedure is ideal for certain short segment and localized obstructions, but might not be the first choice for larger (as seen in the image) or more complicated obstructions.

 

Option B. Femoro-iliac bypass: This surgical procedure reroutes blood flow around a blocked or narrowed iliac artery by creating a bypass using a graft that connects the femoral artery to the iliac artery. It's more localized than an aortofemoral bypass, focusing on the connection between the femoral and iliac arteries in external iliac blocks.

 

Option D. Femoro-popliteal bypass: This procedure is done for distal femoral blocks, which is not the issue described in this patient's case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention for peripheral obstructive vascular disease involving the common iliac artery, particularly when the obstruction is significant and causing symptoms such as claudication.
  •  This procedure helps to restore adequate blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Depression : "Difficult to diagnose due to the shell of physician’s pride" would suggest that physicians might not show or express their symptoms due to professional pride. So, A matches with 3.

 

B. Suicide : "Women physicians, substance abuse, relationship troubles" could be potential risk factors or associated factors. So, B matches with 4.

 

C. Burnout : "State of emotional and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress, relieved after relaxation" perfectly describes burnout. So, C matches with 2.

 

D. Overthinking : "The feeling goes away as soon as you leave the hospital" does not clearly correlate with overthinking, but given the other matches, this seems the closest fit. So, D matches with 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Depression may be masked by professional pride, burnout is reversible with rest, suicide often stems from deeper psychosocial stressors, and overthinking typically resolves when the stressor is removed.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 447, 764.

questions.text: Which medium is best suited for the transport of Streptococcus Pyogenes? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Pike's Medium

 

Explanation

 

Pike's medium is the specialized transport medium for Streptococcus pyogenes. This medium contains blood agar with crystal violet (1 in 1,000,000) and sodium azide (1 in 16,000), which creates selective conditions that inhibit competing bacteria while maintaining the viability of S. pyogenes during transport. These properties make it the optimal choice for transporting specimens suspected to contain this organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stuart's Medium - Stuart's transport medium is designed for handling Neisseria specimens, particularly N. gonorrhoeae. While it's effective for many fastidious organisms, it's not specifically optimized for S. pyogenes transport.

 

Option C. Cary Blair Media - This medium is formulated for enteric pathogens, particularly Vibrio species and Yersinia pestis. Its high pH and low nutrient content make it unsuitable for the optimal transport of S. pyogenes.

 

Option D. Sach's Media - "Sach's buffered glycerol saline" is specifically designed for Shigella specimens. Its composition is not optimized for preserving streptococci during transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pike's medium provides the selective environment necessary for maintaining S. pyogenes viability during specimen transport while preventing overgrowth of contaminating flora.

questions.text: Cannabinoids are not approved for treatment of (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rett syndrome

 

  • Cannabinoids, including cannabidiol (CBD), are not currently approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome. 
  • Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurological disorder, and while there is ongoing research into potential treatments, cannabinoids are not among the approved therapies for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dravet Syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Dravet Syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy. It is used to reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this condition.

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: Cannabidiol (CBD) is also approved for the treatment of seizures associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC). It has been shown to reduce seizure frequency in patients with TSC.

 

Option D. Lennox Gastaut syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, another severe form of epilepsy. It is used to help reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, cannabinoids, specifically cannabidiol (CBD), are not approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome, whereas they are approved for use in Dravet Syndrome, Tuberous Sclerosis, and Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.

questions.text: The components of qSOFA score include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased heart rate

 

Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) scoring system:

 

Other Options:

 

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for:

 

Option A. Altered mental status

 

Option B. Low blood pressure (SBP < 100 mmHg)

 

Option C. High respiratory rate (>22 breaths per min)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequential organ failure assessment score (SOFA score), previously known as the sepsis-related organ failure assessment score, is used to track a person's status during the stay in an intensive care unit (ICU) to determine the extent of a person's organ function or rate of failure.

 

The score is based on six different scores, one each for the respiratory, cardiovascular, hepatic, coagulation, renal and neurological systems.

 

The Quick SOFA Score (quickSOFA or qSOFA) was introduced by the Sepsis-3 group in February 2016 as a simplified version of the SOFA Score as an initial way to identify patients at high risk for poor outcome with an infection.

 

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points near the onset of infection was associated with a greater risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.
