questions.text: Which nerve passes through the foramen marked in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Inferior alveolar nerve

 

The marked structure is the mandibular foramen, which is an opening located just below the mandibular angle.

 

  • The inferior alveolar nerve (IAN) is a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3).
  • The IAN descends behind the lateral pterygoid muscle, passing between the sphenomandibular ligament and the mandibular ramus, and enters the mandibular canal via the mandibular foramen.
  • The mandibular foramen is the entry point for the IAN and the vessels of the mandible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingual nerve:

 

  • It is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is the third division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • The lingual nerve provides general sensory innervation (touch, pain, temperature) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It is closely associated with the chorda tympani nerve (a branch of the facial nerve) which carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the lingual nerve itself doesn't carry taste sensation; it just provides a pathway for the chorda tympani nerve.

 

Option B. Mandibular nerve:

 

  • The mandibular nerve is the third division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), which is the main sensory nerve of the face.
  • It has both sensory and motor components.
  • The sensory branches of the mandibular nerve include the buccal, lingual, and inferior alveolar nerves, which innervate areas such as the lower teeth, gingiva, skin of the cheek, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Its motor fibers innervate the muscles of mastication (chewing) and other muscles like the mylohyoid, anterior belly of the digastric, tensor tympani, and tensor veli palatini.

 

Option C. Chorda tympani nerve:

 

  • It's a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It also carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands, which play a role in salivation.
  • While it is not a branch of the mandibular nerve, it is closely associated with the lingual nerve (a branch of V3) in the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior alveolar nerve is another major branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) which provides sensory innervation to the lower teeth (mandibular teeth) and the surrounding gingiva. Before it enters the mandibular canal in the jaw, it gives off a branch called the mental nerve, which exits the jaw through the mental foramen to supply sensation to the lower lip and chin. The inferior alveolar nerve also carries motor fibers to the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.

questions.text: What among the options serves as a factor that conditions to the development of malnutrition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Infectious diseases

 

Infectious diseases act as conditioning influences that contribute to the development of malnutrition. They can exacerbate malnutrition by increasing morbidity, leading to decreased food intake, loss of nutrients, anorexia, and overall growth failure, which in turn lowers immunity and creates a vicious cycle of poor health.

 

Other 3 Options are not considered as a conditioning influence.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In which of the following transplantations is organ/body size comparison believed to be least important? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pancreas

 

Explanation:

 

Organ size matching is specifically mentioned as important for heart, lung, liver and small bowel transplantation, but not for pancreas transplantation. Allocation of organs must take into account the relative size of the donor and recipient for most organ types. While kidney transplants can be performed between adults and children without significant size concerns, the heart, lung, liver, and small bowel require more careful size matching. The pancreas doesn't appear in discussions of organs requiring strict size compatibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heart - Incorrect. Size compatibility is critically important for heart transplantation. A heart that is too large won't fit in the recipient's chest cavity, while one that's too small may not provide adequate cardiac output for the recipient's body size. Precise size matching is essential for proper cardiac function.

 

Option B. Liver - Incorrect. Size matching is crucial for liver transplantation. An adult donor liver cannot be transplanted into a child because of the size mismatch. This has led to the development of split-liver transplantation, where the liver is divided so the left lobe or left lateral segments can be used for a child and the right lobe for an adult recipient.

 

Option D. Lung - Incorrect. Lung transplantation requires careful size matching to ensure proper fit within the chest cavity. Lungs that are too large cannot physically fit in the recipient's thoracic space, while lungs that are too small may not provide adequate respiratory function for the recipient.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While size matching is critical for heart, lung, liver, and small bowel transplantation, it is comparatively less critical for pancreatic transplantation among the given options.

questions.text: A patient presents with a mobile, warm to touch nodule in the neck. On the anaerobic culture of the biopsy material from this swelling, it showed colonies as shown in the image which had gram-positive branching rods on staining. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penicillin

 

The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth suggestive of actinomycete infection of cervicofacial region also called as Lumpy jaw.

 

Culture characteristics - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth.

 

Gram-positive filamentous branching rods. Non-motile, non-sporing and non-acid-fast. Clumps of the organisms can be seen as yellowish ‘sulphur granules’ in pus discharging from sinus tracts, or the granules can be squeezed out of the lesions.

 

Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin such as amoxicillin are now popular. Clindamycin and erythromycin are effective in patients with penicillin allergy. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: Effective for certain infections but not the first-line treatment for actinomycete infections.

 

Option B. Cotrimoxazole: Not typically used for actinomycete infections.

 

Option D. Surgical drainage: May be required as an adjunct to antibiotic therapy in chronic cases, but it is not the primary treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penicillin is the drug of choice for treating actinomycete infections, particularly in cervicofacial cases presenting with nodules and characteristic colonies. Prolonged antibiotic therapy is necessary, and surgical intervention may be required for chronic lesions.

choices.text: It is a single-stranded RNA virus.
The primary mode of transmission is through the respiratory route.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about Parvovirus B-19: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. It is a single-stranded RNA virus.

 

Explanation:


Parvovirus B-19 is a single-stranded DNA virus, not an RNA virus. This is a fundamental characteristic of the virus. Parvoviridae family viruses are known for being the smallest DNA viruses, with B-19 containing single-stranded DNA within its non-enveloped, icosahedral structure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The primary mode of transmission is through the respiratory route - This statement is correct. Parvovirus B-19 primarily spreads through respiratory droplets, making respiratory transmission the main route of infection. It can also spread through fomites and vertical (mother-to-child) transmission.

 

Option C. It is a DNA virus - This statement is correct. Parvovirus B-19 is definitively a DNA virus, specifically containing single-stranded DNA. This is a key characteristic that distinguishes it from RNA viruses.

 

Option D. It affects erythroid progenitors - This statement is correct. Parvovirus B-19 has a specific tropism for erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. This tropism explains its clinical manifestations including severe anemia, transient aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis in fetuses.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Parvovirus B-19 is a single-stranded DNA virus that primarily infects erythroid progenitor cells, causing conditions like erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), transient aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis in fetuses.

choices.text: The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption
The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock
The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion
The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Cuthbertson's metabolic ebb and flow responses to trauma?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response

 

Explanation

 

The "flow" phase (not "ebb") leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

 

Cuthbertson's ebb and flow response to trauma:

 

A short ebb phase characterized by hypometabolism occurs immediately after the injury and is characterized by a decrease in metabolic rate, oxygen consumption, body temperature, and enzymatic activity. The ebb phase is followed by a longer hypermetabolic flow phase marked by an increased catabolism, with a high oxygen consumption and an elevated resting energy expenditure rate.

 

The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock, which leads to an increased metabolic turnover, activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption: Correct, this describes the initial hypometabolic state following trauma.

 

Option B. The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock: Correct, marking the transition to a hypermetabolic state.

 

Option C. The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion: Correct, as it focuses on conserving energy immediately after trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The statement that the "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response is false. These processes are characteristics of the "flow" phase, which occurs after the initial ebb phase and involves increased metabolic activity and systemic responses aimed at recovery and defense.

questions.text: Otosclerosis most commonly begins at which of the following locations? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fissula Ante-fenestram

 

Explanation:

 

Otosclerosis most commonly begins at the fissula ante fenestram. This is a small depression located in front of the oval window in the otic capsule. This is the initial site where the abnormal bone remodeling process begins, which eventually extends to involve the stapes footplate causing its fixation and conductive hearing loss. The fissula ante fenestrum is considered the classic starting point for otosclerotic lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fossula Post-fenestram: While otosclerotic foci can develop in various locations within the otic capsule, the fossula post-fenestram (behind the oval window) is not the most common initial site. Otosclerosis predominantly begins at the area anterior to the oval window (fissula ante fenestram).

 

Option C. Footplate of Stapes: Although the stapes footplate is eventually involved in otosclerosis, leading to the characteristic stapes fixation and conductive hearing loss, it is not typically the primary site where the disease process begins. The disease usually starts in the fissula ante fenestram and then extends to involve the footplate.

 

Option D. Oval Window: The oval window itself is not the initial site of otosclerotic change. The oval window is the opening between the middle and inner ear into which the stapes footplate fits. Otosclerosis begins in the bone adjacent to this structure (in the fissula ante fenestram) and then extends to involve the stapes footplate and oval window area.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Otosclerosis characteristically begins in the fissula ante fenestram (anterior to the oval window) before extending to involve the stapes footplate, causing the fixation that leads to conductive hearing loss.

choices.text: The most common mechanism involves the production of neutralizing enzymes by bacteria.
Plasmid-mediated resistance is transmitted exclusively through vertical transmission.
The complete elimination of the target binding site may contribute to vancomycin resistance in some enterococci.
Alteration of the target binding site contributes to antibiotic resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae.

questions.text: Regarding antibiotic resistance, which of the following statements is NOT true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Plasmid-mediated resistance is transmitted exclusively through vertical transmission.

 

Explanation:


Plasmid-mediated resistance is NOT transmitted exclusively through vertical transmission. This statement is false because plasmids are primarily transferred horizontally between bacteria through conjugation (direct cell-to-cell contact), transduction (via bacteriophages), or transformation (uptake of DNA from the environment). This horizontal transfer is what makes plasmid-mediated resistance particularly problematic in clinical settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The most common mechanism involves the production of neutralizing enzymes by bacteria - This is true. Many bacteria produce enzymes like beta-lactamases that can degrade or modify antibiotics, rendering them ineffective. This is a major mechanism of resistance against beta-lactam antibiotics.

 

Option C. The complete elimination of the target binding site may contribute to vancomycin resistance in some enterococci - This is true. Vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) can alter peptidoglycan precursors so they no longer contain the D-Ala-D-Ala terminal sequences to which vancomycin binds.

 

Option D. Alteration of the target binding site contributes to antibiotic resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae - This is true. S. pneumoniae can develop resistance to penicillins through alterations in penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), which are the target binding sites for beta-lactam antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmid-mediated resistance is primarily spread through horizontal gene transfer mechanisms (conjugation, transduction, and transformation), making it particularly efficient at spreading resistance genes within bacterial populations and between different bacterial species.

questions.text: Which of the following atypical antipsychotics has the highest risk of galactorrhea? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Risperidone

 

The antipsychotics work by blocking the D2 receptors in various parts of the brain. The dopaminergic block in the Tuberoinfundibular pathway leads to increase in the levels of Prolactin (As physiologically Dopamine has a negative feedback effect on Prolactin). Typical antipsychotics like Haloperidol have a very high risk of hyperprolactinemia. Among the atypical antipsychotics, Risperidone has the highest risk of galactorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iloperidone: Iloperidone has a lower risk of causing hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea compared to risperidone.

 

Option C. Clozapine: Clozapine has a relatively lower risk of causing hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea among atypical antipsychotics. It is known for its efficacy in treatment-resistant schizophrenia but has other significant side effects, such as agranulocytosis.

 

Option D. Aripiprazole: Aripiprazole is a partial agonist at D2 receptors and is associated with a lower risk of hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea. In some cases, it can even be used to counteract hyperprolactinemia caused by other antipsychotics.

 

Mechanism of Hyperprolactinemia

 

  • Dopamine: Acts as an inhibitory regulator of prolactin secretion via D2 receptors in the tuberoinfundibular pathway.
  • Antipsychotics: By blocking D2 receptors, they remove this inhibition, leading to increased prolactin levels.
  • Prolactin: Elevated levels can lead to galactorrhea, menstrual disturbances, and sexual dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risperidone is the atypical antipsychotic with the highest risk of causing galactorrhea due to its potent D2 receptor antagonism in the tuberoinfundibular pathway, leading to increased prolactin levels.

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interferon gamma release assay

 

TB test done on a whole blood sample is the interferon-gamma release assay. It has been used for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in patients with HIV (who frequently have a negative Mantoux test).

 

Interferon-gamma release assays include:

 

  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold
  • T-SPOT.TB

 

QuantiFERON-TB Gold quantitates the amount of IN- produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CD8+ and CD4+ T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens.

 

T-SPOT.TB determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing IFN-v.

 

The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB in one hour as well as test for rifampicin resistance. This test uses a sputum sample taken from the patient. Only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required. Gene Xpert is also a molecular method of testing that cannot use blood as a sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TrueNat TB: Incorrect, as this molecular test diagnoses TB and tests for rifampicin resistance using a sputum sample, not whole blood.

 

Option B. Gene Xpert: Incorrect, this is another molecular test that identifies TB and resistance to rifampicin but also uses sputum samples rather than whole blood.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect, as only the interferon gamma release assay is designed to be used with whole blood samples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Interferon gamma release assay is a valuable tool for diagnosing latent TB, particularly suitable for patients who may not be effectively diagnosed through traditional skin tests, offering a sensitive and specific method that utilizes whole blood to detect an immune response to TB antigens.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent episodes of respiratory infections, primarily caused by bacteria with polysaccharide-rich capsules. Which immunoglobulin subclass deficiency is most likely to be responsible for these infections? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. IgG2

 

Explanation:


IgG2 antibody is specifically directed against polysaccharide antigens and is the most important defense against encapsulated bacteria. When a child has a deficiency in this particular IgG subclass, they become highly susceptible to recurrent infections with polysaccharide-encapsulated bacteria, which commonly cause respiratory infections. These include pathogens like Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and other bacteria with prominent polysaccharide capsules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgA - While IgA deficiency is the most common immunodeficiency and can lead to respiratory infections, it primarily affects mucosal immunity rather than specific defense against encapsulated bacteria. IgA deficiency typically manifests as increased susceptibility to sinopulmonary infections and diarrhea.

 

Option B. IgG1 - This is the most abundant IgG subclass (65% of total IgG) and responds primarily to protein antigens, not polysaccharide capsules. A deficiency would cause broad susceptibility to infections but not specifically to encapsulated bacteria.

 

Option D. IgG3 - This subclass typically responds to protein antigens rather than polysaccharides. IgG3 deficiency would not specifically predispose to infections with encapsulated bacteria.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

IgG2 is the critical immunoglobulin subclass for defense against encapsulated bacteria with polysaccharide-rich capsules, making its deficiency the most likely cause of recurrent respiratory infections with these specific pathogens.

questions.text: Water's view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

Waters’ view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position). The X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.

 

In this view, petrous bones are projected below the maxillary antra.

 

Structures seen are:

 

  1. Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  2. Frontal sinuses
  3. Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth).
  4. Zygoma
  5. Zygomatic arch
  6. Nasal bone.
  7. Frontal process of maxilla
  8. Superior orbital fissure
  9. Intratemporal fossa.

 

Other 3 Options: Not best visualized in Water's view as this technique primarily highlights the maxillary and other larger sinuses.
 

Educational Objective:
 

Water's view is particularly effective for visualizing the maxillary sinus, making it an essential diagnostic tool in sinus imaging, especially when evaluating issues related to the maxillary sinuses.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Support and education

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks.

 

The primary management for postpartum blues is support and education about the condition, emphasizing its transient nature and differentiating it from the more severe postpartum depression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Useful in postpartum depression but not needed for the milder blues.

 

Option B. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial for postpartum depression but is not the primary treatment for transient postpartum blues.

 

Option C. Lithium carbonate: Not indicated for postpartum blues or depression; used mainly for bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 839.

choices.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment
Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depression is a common comorbidity

 

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition characterized by intrusive, repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and the urge to perform repetitive behaviors or rituals (compulsions).

 

Many individuals with OCD also suffer from depression. The two conditions can coexist and may even be related in some manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment: This is false. The first-line treatments for OCD are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), clomipramine and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Atypical antipsychotics may be added as an adjunctive treatment in patients who do not respond to standard treatments.

 

Option B. Prevalence is 7-10 percent in general population: This is incorrect. The prevalence of OCD in the general population is around 2-3%.

 

Option D. Contamination is an uncommon obsession: False. Contamination obsessions are the most common types of obsessions in OCD. Individuals may fear germs or becoming ill and may wash their hands excessively as a result.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OCD is characterized by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 95-97.

questions.text: Where are lipid rafts typically observed? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Plasma membrane

 

Explanation:


Lipid rafts are specialized microdomains within the plasma membrane that are enriched in cholesterol and sphingolipids. These membrane regions serve as organizing centers for the assembly of signaling molecules and influence membrane fluidity and protein trafficking. When these rafts become infiltrated with caveolin protein, they form flask-shaped membrane depressions called caveolae ("little caves").

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Ribosomes - Ribosomes are cellular structures composed of RNA and protein that function as sites of protein synthesis. They lack the lipid bilayer structure necessary for lipid raft formation.
  • Option b. Mitochondria - While mitochondria have an inner and outer membrane, lipid rafts are specifically located in the cell membrane (plasma membrane), not in mitochondrial membranes.
  • Option d. ER - The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a membrane-bound organelle involved in protein synthesis and lipid metabolism. Though it contains membranes, lipid rafts are primarily identified and characterized in the plasma membrane.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lipid rafts are cholesterol and sphingolipid-rich microdomains in the plasma membrane that can develop into caveolae and play important roles in cellular signaling, cholesterol regulation, and transcytosis.

choices.text: It is made from cat gut
It is made from rabbit gut
It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis
It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue

questions.text: Which of the following is true about chromic catgut? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

 

True. Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture, which means that it gets absorbed by the body over time. The process involves enzymatic degradation (breaking down by enzymes) and phagocytosis by macrophages (special cells that engulf and digest foreign substances, microbes, and cellular debris).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is made from cat gut: While the term "catgut" might suggest that the material is derived from cats, this is a misnomer. Catgut suture material is historically derived from the submucosal layer of sheep or goat intestines. The term is a shortened version of the word "cattlegut."

 

Option B. It is made from rabbit gut: This statement is also misleading. As mentioned, the primary sources for catgut are sheep and goat intestines, not rabbit.

 

Option D. It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue: This statement is inaccurate in the context of chromic catgut. Chromic catgut is treated with chromium salts, not nickel salts. Chromium salts are used to cross-link the collagen fibers in the catgut, which increases its resistance to degradation, thus prolonging its time before being absorbed in the tissue. This treatment also improves the suture's handling properties.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture material derived from sheep or goat intestines and is absorbed in the body through enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

questions.text: Infections of the middle ear can extend to the brain through all of the following routes, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spread through Lymphatic Channels

 

Explanation:

 

Middle ear infections do not spread to the brain through lymphatic channels because there are no lymphatic connections between the middle ear and intracranial structures. The brain and cranial cavity lack a traditional lymphatic system. Infection from the middle ear to the brain occurs through other routes including direct bone erosion, preformed pathways, or hematogenous spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Bony Invasion: This is a common route of intracranial spread of middle ear infection. Cholesteatoma or chronic infection can erode the tegmen tympani (roof of middle ear), allowing infection to spread to the middle cranial fossa causing extradural or subdural abscess. Similarly, erosion of the posterior wall can lead to cerebellar abscess.

 

Option B. Oval or Round Window: These are preformed pathways through which infection can spread from the middle ear to the inner ear (labyrinthitis), and then to the internal auditory canal and cerebellopontine angle through the cochlear aqueduct or internal auditory canal. The subarachnoid space can be accessed through the cochlear aqueduct, which connects the scala tympani with the subarachnoid space.

 

Option C. Spread via Bloodstream: Hematogenous spread is another valid route where infection spreads through venous channels, particularly through emissary veins or by thrombophlebitis of the sigmoid sinus. This can lead to lateral sinus thrombosis, meningitis, or brain abscess.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While middle ear infections can spread to intracranial structures through direct bone erosion, preformed pathways (oval/round windows), and bloodstream, there is no lymphatic route for such spread since the brain lacks traditional lymphatics.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a known allergy to penicillin presents with a enterococcal endocarditis. The physician needs to prescribe an antibiotic but wants to ensure it is safe for a patient with a penicillin allergy. The patient has had previous allergic reactions to penicillin, including rash and swelling. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in a patient allergic to penicillin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

  • The clinical scenario involves a 45-year-old patient with enterococcal endocarditis and a known allergy to penicillin, presenting with previous allergic reactions including rash and swelling. 
  • The physician needs to choose an antibiotic that is safe for a patient with a penicillin allergy as well as effective for enterococcal endocarditis. Let's review the options:
  • Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is not related to penicillin. 
  • It is safe for patients with penicillin allergies and is commonly used to treat gram-positive infections, including those caused by enterococci.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic that is generally considered safe for patients with penicillin allergies because it does not share the beta-lactam ring structure of penicillins, which is typically responsible for allergic reactions. However, aztreonam is effective only against gram negative bacteria and is not suitable for enterococcal infections which is a gram positive bacteria.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin. Although cephalosporins have a beta-lactam ring similar to penicillins, the rate of cross-reactivity is relatively low, especially with third-generation cephalosporins. However, caution is advised in patients with a history of severe penicillin allergy.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: Piperacillin is a penicillin derivative and should be avoided in patients with penicillin allergies due to the high risk of cross-reactivity and potential for severe allergic reactions.

 

Conclusion

 

The safest options for a patient with a penicillin allergy are:

 

Aztreonam (Option a)

 

Vancomycin (Option b)

 

Given the specific need to avoid penicillin and its derivatives and to treat gram positive (enterococcal) infections, Vancomycin is a safe and effective choice for treating enterococcal endocarditis in this patient. Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

b. Vancomycin

questions.text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trotter’s method

 

The image shows Trotter's method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epley's maneuver: Is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

 

 

Option C. Mc Govern technique: A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway. It is used as an emergency management may be required in bilateral choanal atresia to provide an airway.

 

 

Option D. Valsalva maneuver: A technique where the patient forcefully exhales while keeping the mouth and nose closed. This increases intrathoracic pressure and is used in various medical situations, including adjusting ear pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trotter’s method is an effective first-line intervention for controlling epistaxis. It emphasizes maintaining an upright, forward-leaning posture to minimize blood swallowing and facilitate proper drainage, essential for patient comfort and safety during a nosebleed episode.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No.  183, 199

questions.text: A tumor arising from the uncinate process of the pancreas is most likely to compress which of the following vessels? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Superior mesenteric artery

 

A tumor of the uncinate process of pancreas affects the superior mesenteric artery.

 

Superior mesenteric artery originates from the anterior surface of the aorta just below the celiac trunk. It supplies blood to the midgut structures, including parts of the small intestine and the proximal large intestine.

 

Anatomically, the uncinate process of the pancreas lies posterior to the SMA, and its proximity means that tumors arising from the uncinate process can compress or invade the SMA.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Portal vein: It is formed posterior to the neck of the pancreas by the confluence of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein. It conveys blood from the gastrointestinal tract and spleen to the liver. While tumors of the pancreas can involve the portal vein, especially those in the head and neck region, the uncinate process's direct relationship is more with the Superior mesenteric artery than with the portal vein.

 

Option C. Common hepatic artery: The common hepatic artery typically arises from the celiac trunk and bifurcates into the proper hepatic artery (supplying the liver) and the gastroduodenal artery. It runs superior to the head of the pancreas. While it's possible for a pancreatic tumor to involve this artery, especially if the tumor is extensive, the uncinate process's primary vascular relationship remains the Superior mesenteric artery.

 

Option D. Inferior mesenteric artery: It is the third major branch of the abdominal aorta and supplies blood to the hindgut structures, including the distal part of the large intestine. It is anatomically distant from the uncinate process of the pancreas, so it's less likely to be directly affected by a tumor in this location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uncinate process of the pancreas is a small extension of the pancreas that hooks around the superior mesenteric artery and vein. Its anatomical relations include:

 

Superiorly:

 

  • Neck of the pancreas

 

Inferiorly:

 

  • Superior mesenteric vein
  • Superior mesenteric artery

 

Anteriorly:

 

  • Third part of the duodenum
  • Root of the small bowel mesentery

 

Posteriorly:

 

  • Inferior vena cava
  • Aorta
  • Left renal vein
  • Left psoas muscle
  • Transverse mesocolon

 

Medially:

 

  • Pancreatic duct
  • Common bile duct

 

Laterally:

 

  • Right renal vessels
  • Right psoas muscle

 

The uncinate process is an important landmark for the surgeon during pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) as it is often involved in the dissection of the superior mesenteric vein and artery.Top of Form

questions.text: Which of the following is not a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insidious onset of symptoms

 

Insidious onset of symptoms, where the symptoms develop slowly and subtly over time, tends to indicate a poorer prognosis when compared to an abrupt or sudden onset of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Schizophrenia's prognosis varies based on several factors:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Positive symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions are usually more responsive to antipsychotic medications, marking them as a better prognostic factor.

 

Option B. Late age of onset: Late age of onset indeed is a better prognostic factor. Early-onset schizophrenia tends to be more severe and has a poorer prognosis than schizophrenia that begins in adulthood.

 

Option D. Associated with depression: If a patient with schizophrenia also has depressive symptoms, the prognosis might be somewhat better since affective symptoms might respond to treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 62.

questions.text: You are a researcher aiming to compile and analyze data from various independent studies to enhance the precision of treatment effect estimates for a specific medical condition. Which of the following methodologies is most appropriate for achieving this objective? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Meta-analysis

 

Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality:

 

  • 1st preference: Meta-analysis
  • 2nd preference: Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  • 3rd preference: Retrospective (Non-concurrent/ Historical) cohort study
  • 4th preference: Prospective cohort study (Concurrent cohort study)
  • 5th preference: Case control study
  • 6th preference: Cross-sectional study
  • 7th preference: Ecological study

 

Meta-analysis

 

  • An objective, systematic review that employs statistical methods to combine and summarize the results of several studies. 
  • A quantitative synthesis of all unbiased evidence, meant for summarizing large volume of data, establishing and determining the magnitude of an effect, and to increase power and precision of studies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Observational study design, not suitable for synthesizing data from multiple studies.

 

Option B. Systematic review: Provides a qualitative synthesis of evidence but does not statistically combine results.

 

Option D. RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial): Primary study design, not a method for combining results from multiple studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meta-analysis is the most effective quantitative approach for synthesizing data from multiple research studies to derive a more precise estimate of the treatment effect.
  • Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality - 1st preference is - Meta-analysis

questions.text: In a study involving a population, where the mean value is 200, if the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 180-220

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD →Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD →Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD →Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

So, 68% population will cover, Mean ± 1SD.

Mean = 200

Standard Deviation = 20

 

68% population will lie between = 200 ± 20 = 180 - 220

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.text: Which of these options is not part of the Global Hunger Index (GHI)? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

  • Infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI).
  • The three components of the GHI are - 
    • Inadequate food supply [PNU – Undernourished Population]
    • Child mortality (under the age of 5) [U5M – Under 5 Mortality]
    • Malnutrition (wasting, stunting) [CUW – Child underweight]

 

The GHI is a tool used to measure and track hunger at global, regional, and national levels.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) does not include the infant mortality rate. It focuses on inadequate food supply, child mortality under the age of five, and child undernutrition as its key components to assess hunger and malnutrition.

choices.text: Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior metal wall
Widening of meatus and facial nerve palsy might be seen

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about keratosis obturans? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

All of the above statements are true regarding keratosis obturans.

 

  • Collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus is called keratosis obturans. This, by its pressure effect, causes absorption of bone leading to widening of the meatus so much so that facial nerves may be exposed and paralyzed.
  • Presenting symptoms may be pain in the ear, hearing loss, tinnitus and sometimes ear discharge. It may sometimes be associated with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.
  • On examination, the ear canal may be full of pearly white mass of keratin material disposed in several layers. Removal of this mass may show widening of bony meatus with ulceration and even granuloma formation.

 

 

Treatment

 

Keratotic mass is removed either by syringing or instrumentation, similar to the techniques employed for impacted wax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratosis obturans is characterized by the accumulation of epithelial cells in the ear canal, leading to potential structural damage and associated symptoms. Its management requires careful removal of the buildup and monitoring for complications such as facial nerve palsy. Awareness of its association with bronchiectasis and sinusitis is crucial for comprehensive patient care.

questions.text: Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulphur granules in pus, are caused by:  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Actinomyces

 

Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulfur granules in pus, are characteristic of actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces.

 

Actinomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by indurated swellings mainly in the connective tissue with suppuration and discharge of sulfur granules. The most common causative agent is Actinomyces israelli

 

Various clinical forms of actinomycosis include cervicofacial, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic actinomycosis.

 

Among them, actinomycosis most commonly occurs as oral-cervicofacial form presenting as a soft tissue swelling, abscess, or mass lesion involving the angle of the jaw.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nocardia: Incorrect, although Nocardia can also cause cutaneous infections with abscess and sinus formation, it does not produce sulfur granules.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Incorrect, known primarily for causing gastrointestinal infections rather than chronic skin and soft tissue infections.

 

Option D. Tularemia: Incorrect, although it can cause ulceroglandular disease with skin ulcers and lymphadenopathy, it does not produce sulfur granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actinomycosis, particularly its cervicofacial form, is characterized by the formation of abscesses that discharge pus containing sulfur granules. This hallmark feature helps in diagnosing the disease, which requires prolonged antibiotic therapy due to its chronic and indurative nature.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg had a sodium level of 120 mEq, calculate sodium deficit? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 840 mEq

 

Explanation

 

The sodium deficit in the given scenario is 840 mEq.

 

Formula for calculating sodium deficit = 0.6 × body weight x (target plasma sodium concentration - starting plasma sodium concentration).

 

Substituting values as per the question,

 

Sodium deficit = 0.6 x 70 × (140 - 120) = 840 mEq.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correcting sodium levels must be done cautiously, especially in cases of hyponatremia, to prevent complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. Rapid changes in serum sodium can be dangerous, and adjustments should generally be made slowly, according to specific clinical guidelines.

questions.text: Which fontanelle is the last to close during normal skull development? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior

 

The anterior fontanelle (Bregma) is the largest and most prominent fontanelle on a baby's skull.

 

The anterior fontanelle is the last fontanelle to close. It closes at around 18-24 months of age.

 

These openings in the skull allow for flexibility during childbirth and rapid brain growth during infancy. Fontanelles gradually close as the bones of the skull grow and fuse.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Fontanelle (Lambda):

 

  • The posterior fontanelle is located at the junction of the occipital and parietal bones of the skull. Unlike the anterior fontanelle, the posterior fontanelle is smaller and less noticeable.
  • The posterior fontanelle usually closes within the first few months of life.

 

Option C. Occipital Fontanelle (Sphenoidal):

 

  • The term "occipital fontanelle" is less commonly used, and it may refer to a small soft spot located at the back of the head, near the occipital bone. This area is generally less significant than the anterior and posterior fontanelles and closes early in infancy.

 

Option D. Mastoid Fontanelle:

 

  • The term "mastoid fontanelle" is not commonly used in the context of fontanelles on a baby's skull.
  • The mastoid region of the skull is a bony area located behind the ear, and it does not typically have a soft spot or fontanelle.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A pediatrician is reviewing mortality trends among children aged between 1-4 years based on verbal autopsy reports from the years 2010-2013. She wants to educate parents on the primary causes of death to improve preventive measures in her community. From the list provided below, which sequence correctly represents the leading causes of death in a descending order for this age group? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Pneumonia
  3. Malaria
  4. Injuries
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 2>1>4>3

 

  • According to the verbal autopsy report of 2010-2013, leading cause of death among 1–4-year-old children in a developing country like India in descending order is Pneumonia > Diarrhea > Injuries > Malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a developed country, leading causes of death are:

 

  1. Accident injury
  2. Congenital anomaly
  3. Neoplasms
  4. Influenza
  5. Pneumonia

choices.text: Opening of calcium channels

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opening of calcium channels

 

Explanation

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure varies widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)

 

1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE

 

Whenever, the blood flow to kidneys increases,  →  stretches the elastic wall of the afferent arteriole →  Stretching of the vessel wall increases the flow of calcium ions from extracellular fluid into the cells →  The influx of calcium ions leads to the contraction of smooth muscles in afferent arteriole, which causes constriction of afferent arteriole →  So, the blood flow is decreased.

 

 

2. TGF

 

The macula densa, a plaque of specialized tubular epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, monitors the NaCl concentration of the tubular fluid and sends an as of yet unidentified signal to control glomerular hemodynamics. In this mechanism, called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF), an increase in NaCl concentration at the macula densa constricts the glomerular afferent arteriole and thus decreases the single-nephron GFR. Along with the myogenic response, TGF significantly contributes to renal autoregulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NO: Incorrect, as nitric oxide generally causes vasodilation, not the contraction associated with the myogenic response.

 

Option B. Noradrenaline: Incorrect, although noradrenaline can affect blood vessel tone, it is not directly involved in the myogenic response mechanism of renal autoregulation.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Incorrect, adenosine is more involved in tubuloglomerular feedback rather than the myogenic mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In renal autoregulation, the myogenic hypothesis states that the afferent arterioles contract in response to increased blood pressure, which stretches the arteriole walls. This contraction is mediated by the opening of calcium channels, leading to an influx of calcium ions and subsequent constriction of the arteriole, thereby helping to stabilize GFR across varying blood pressures.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Half fall in 10 min

 

Half fall in 10 min: This is correct. The Miami Criteria for successful parathyroidectomy require a drop in PTH level of more than 50% from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the removal of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

The Miami Criteria, also known as the Miami Intraoperative Criteria, refers to a set of guidelines used to confirm successful removal of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue during parathyroidectomy. The criteria are based on intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

According to the Miami Criteria, a successful parathyroidectomy is indicated if there is a drop in PTH level of more than 50% (half) from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the adenoma. This significant decrease indicates that the source of excess PTH production has been successfully removed.

 

The utility of this approach is that it allows for immediate feedback during surgery about whether all hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue has been removed, reducing the chances of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quarter fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. The Miami Criteria specify a 50% (half) fall, not a 25% (quarter) fall, and the timeframe is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Option B. Quarter fall in 10 min: This is incorrect. While the 10-minute timeframe is correct, the required decrease is 50% (half), not 25% (quarter).

 

Option C. Half fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. Although the 50% (half) fall is correct, the timeframe specified by the Miami Criteria is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Miami Criteria for intraoperative PTH measurement indicate a successful parathyroidectomy if there is a 50% or greater drop in PTH level from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with a positive Hitzelberger sign. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vestibular schwannoma

 

Explanation:

 

A positive Hitzelberger sign indicates hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall in the external auditory canal. This sign is pathognomonic for acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma). Hitzelberger sign occurs when the nervus intermedius (sensory branch of facial nerve) is compressed in the internal auditory canal by the growing tumor. It is considered the first sign that indicates facial nerve involvement in acoustic neuroma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mastoiditis: This is an infection of the mastoid air cells that presents with postauricular pain, tenderness, and swelling. Signs include "ironing of mastoid surface" (smooth & shiny look), mastoid tenderness, and sagging of the posterior meatal wall. Hitzelberger sign is not associated with mastoiditis.

 

Option C. Bell's palsy: This is an idiopathic facial paralysis presenting with unilateral facial weakness. While it affects the facial nerve, Bell's palsy doesn't typically cause hypoesthesia of the posterior canal wall. Bell's palsy affects the motor component of the facial nerve, not the sensory fibers that would produce Hitzelberger sign.

 

Option D. Middle ear cholesteatoma: This is "skin in the wrong place" - keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear. It can cause ossicular destruction and various complications, but Hitzelberger sign is not one of them. Cholesteatoma affects the middle ear structures, not the internal auditory canal where compression causing Hitzelberger sign occurs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hitzelberger sign (decreased sensation in the posterior meatal wall) is pathognomonic for vestibular schwannoma and represents early involvement of the facial nerve as the tumor compresses the nervus intermedius in the internal auditory canal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) H.ducreyi

 

Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid (Soft Chancre), a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy, not urethritis. Urethritis involves inflammation of the urethra, typically presenting with symptoms such as dysuria and discharge. H. ducreyi specifically causes ulcerative lesions rather than the typical inflammation and discharge associated with urethritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: While primarily known for causing trichomoniasis (a vaginitis), Trichomonas can occasionally cause urethritis, particularly in women.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, particularly among sexually transmitted bacterial infections.

 

Option C. Gonococcus (Neisseria gonorrhoeae): A well-known cause of gonococcal urethritis, presenting typically with a more severe and purulent discharge compared to NGU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urethritis is classified into two types:

 

  1. Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
  2. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Adenovirus
    • Haemophilus vaginalis
    • Mycoplasma genitalium
    • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
    • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favor of delirium? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating course

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset and a fluctuating course, often varying in severity throughout the day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs gradually over a period of time: This is more suggestive of dementia rather than delirium.

 

Option C. Preserved consciousness: The characteristic feature of delirium is a disturbance in consciousness and attention. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: While hallucinations can be present in delirium, they aren't specific to it. Schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders might also present with auditory hallucinations.

 

Therefore, a fluctuating course is the most suggestive of delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is the most common organic mental disorder. It has an acute onset with a fluctuating course. It is most commonly seen in elderly population. It is characterized by disturbed consciousness, and altered attention. Disturbances of sleep-wake cycle, evening worsening of symptoms (sundowning), and floccillations can be seen.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook osf Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing applied? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kirby-Bauer method

 

The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method.

 

To perform Kirby-Bauer's disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive).

 

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

 

  • Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method
  • Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method
  • Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E-test (Epsilometer)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agar dilution method: This method involves incorporating different concentrations of antibiotics into agar plates. It's primarily a quantitative technique that provides the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of antibiotics.

 

Option C. Broth dilution method: Similar to the agar dilution method but performed in a liquid medium. This method also determines the MIC of antibiotics.

 

Option D. PCR based assay: This molecular method detects the presence of specific antibiotic resistance genes but does not directly test the susceptibility of bacteria to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method is a straightforward and widely used technique for assessing bacterial antibiotic susceptibility, providing vital information for the appropriate selection of antibiotics in clinical settings. It is essential for effective antimicrobial stewardship and the management of bacterial infections.

choices.text: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
When 02 and CO2 ratio is equal
The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg

questions.text: V/Q = infinity holds true in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Equal to dead space

 

Explanation

 

VA/Q= infinity suggests that Q is 0 which implies that there is no exchange of 02 & CO2, and no gaseous exchange occurs in dead space.

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus: Incorrect, as this condition would lead to an area with no ventilation (blocked by the foreign body) potentially resulting in a low V/Q ratio in the affected area rather than an infinite V/Q ratio.

 

Option C. When O2 and CO2 ratio is equal: Incorrect, as this does not directly relate to the ventilation-perfusion ratio concept. This option is more a reflection of gas exchange effectiveness rather than a description of V/Q mismatches.

 

Option D. The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg: Incorrect, these values are typical for normal alveolar air and do not indicate a V/Q mismatch situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VA /Q ratio is infinite in the following scenarios -

 

  1. Ventilation is normal but there is no perfusion.
  2. No gaseous exchange through the respiratory membranes of corresponding alveoli.
  3. The alveolar air equilibrates the humidified inspired air.
  4. Partial pressures of the 02 and CO, are 149 mmHg & 0 mm Hg respectively.

questions.text: You're mentoring a group of budding epidemiologists who are keen on understanding the nuances of different study designs. One of them is particularly interested in case-control studies. During your discussion, you decide to quiz them on aspects that are typically not inherent to case-control studies. Which of the given options would not usually be part of a case-control study? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Follow up 

 

  • Follow up is not a component of case-control studies.
  • These studies are retrospective and do not involve tracking subjects over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Matching: Process of selecting controls in a such a way that they are similar to cases (with regard to certain pertinent selected variables which may influence the outcome of disease, thereby distorting the results). It eliminates confounding.

 

Option C. Strength of association: In case-control studies, the strength of association is measured using the odds ratio (an estimate of relative risk).

 

Option D. Selection of study subjects: Essential in case-control studies, involving the selection of cases with the disease and controls without the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case-control studies do not include follow-up of subjects but focus on matching, assessing the strength of association using odds ratios, and selecting cases and controls for analysis.

questions.text: Maximum absorption of short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria occurs in the: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Colon

 

Explanation:

 

Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are primarily produced in the colon and absorbed from it. These 2-5 carbon weak acids have an average concentration of about 80 mmol/L in the colonic lumen, with acetate (60%), propionate (25%), and butyrate (15%) being the predominant types. They form through bacterial fermentation of complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and dietary fiber components that escape digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Stomach - The stomach primarily handles initial protein digestion and fat emulsification. The acidic environment is not conducive to the bacterial fermentation processes that generate SCFAs.
  • Option B. Duodenum - The duodenum is involved in the early stages of nutrient digestion with pancreatic enzymes and bile, but not in SCFA production or absorption. Bacterial populations needed for SCFA production are minimal here.
  • Option C. Jejunum - While the jejunum is a major site for nutrient absorption, it lacks the significant bacterial populations required for SCFA production. The relatively fast transit time also does not allow for substantial bacterial fermentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCFAs are unique among fatty acids in that they're produced by bacterial fermentation in the colon and represent an important source of energy for colonic epithelial cells, helping maintain mucosal integrity and acid-base balance.
